title: 113_s2865
content: The Act titled "Voter Registration Modernization Act" requires the availability of internet for voter registration, amending the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 to include a new section on internet registration. The Voter Registration Modernization Act mandates that each State must provide online voter registration services on their official websites, including online application, assistance, and submission of voter registration forms. The Voter Registration Modernization Act requires States to accept online voter registration applications that meet the same requirements as mail-in registrations. The Voter Registration Modernization Act mandates that individuals must provide matching information with the State motor vehicle authority or an electronic signature when submitting an online voter registration application. Signatures can be in electronic form by executing a computerized mark or submitting an electronic copy of a handwritten signature. Services provided under this act must be nonpartisan. The Voter Registration Modernization Act requires online applications to be nonpartisan and not influence political preferences. States must implement security measures to protect information and ensure nondiscrimination among registered voters using mail and online registration. Online Registration under the Voter Registration Modernization Act mandates that states treat online registered voters the same as those registered by mail. Accessibility for individuals with disabilities, including privacy and independence, must be ensured. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to allow first-time voter identification requirements to be completed online. Conforming amendments include timing of registration for online registration through the official public website of an election official. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to allow first-time voter registration online under section 6A, with a deadline of 30 days before the election. Section 8(a)(5) is updated to include the new online registration process. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to allow first-time voter registration online under section 6A, with a deadline of 30 days before the election. Section 8(a)(5) is updated to include the new online registration process. Use of internet to update registration information is authorized. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 now allows registered voters to update their information online through the official election website. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 permits registered voters to update their information online by providing an electronic signature, which will be processed by election officials to reflect any changes in the voter's eligibility for Federal elections. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 allows registered voters to update their information online for Federal elections by providing an electronic signature. This includes updating information on residence within a specified timeframe before the election date. Amendments are made to ensure the effective date and the ability of registrants to use online updates for information updates. Amendments to the Help America Vote Act of 2002 allow registered voters to update their information online for Federal elections. This includes updating residence information before the election date. The changes ensure the effective date and the ability to use online updates for information changes. SEC. 4. STUDY ON BEST PRACTICES FOR INTERNET REGISTRATION. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will conduct a study on best practices for Internet voter registration and updating voter information online. A report on the study must be made available within 4 months of the enactment of this Act, with updates every four years. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will provide voluntary guidance on best practices for Internet voter registration, utilizing the best practices developed under the Voter Registration Modernization Act. SEC. 5. PROVISION OF ELECTION INFORMATION BY ELECTRONIC MAIL TO INDIVIDUALS REGISTERED TO VOTE. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to include an option for applicants to provide their email address on the registration form to receive voting information electronically. The National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to allow applicants to provide their email address on the registration form for receiving voting information electronically. The email address provided must only be used for official purposes by election officials and not shared with anyone else. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 now requires election officials to provide registered voters with voting information via email if the voter has provided their email address for this purpose. This information must be sent at least 30 days before the election. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 mandates election officials to email registered voters voting information, including polling place location, hours of operation, and required identification, at least 30 days before the election. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF VOTER ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. Section 8 of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 is amended to include a new subsection (j) which requires states to register applicants who provide necessary information to show eligibility to vote. This includes accurately completing the application form and attesting to the required statement. The applicant must provide a signature in accordance with section 6A. SEC. 7. IMPLEMENTATION PAYMENTS. The Election Assistance Commission provides annual implementation payments to each State to meet the requirements of the Act. States can also use the funds for other election administration activities if they have implemented the Act's requirements and stay within the specified amount. The Election Assistance Commission provides annual implementation payments to States based on the total amount appropriated and the State allocation percentage, following rules similar to the Help America Vote Act of 2002. The Election Assistance Commission authorizes $15,000,000 for implementation payments in fiscal year 2015, with funds remaining available until expended. States must submit reports on activities conducted with these funds by April 1, 2017. The amendments made by the Act will take effect on January 1, 2016, unless a State certifies by January 1, 2016, that it cannot meet the deadline with good cause, in which case the deadline will be extended to January 1, 2018.
